>>28119407
>Do I sound pathetic and unlovable like I feel a lot of the time?
Well, to be blunt, *feeling* pathetic and unlovable is a self-fulfilling prophecy.

There's an oldfag hangs around here occasionally who describes himself as an ex-incel; he likes to say that it isn't that you're an incel because you don't get laid, it's that you don't get laid because you're an incel. That might might be too harsh a way to describe you - your post isn't giving off incel-belief-system vibes, which is a good thing, but I suspect you're in a similar position. What that guy means is that the key to not being an incel is letting go of your incel beliefs.

Nothing that you say about yourself makes you sound like a *necessarily* unattractive person; but so long as you go around actively radiating "no one could possibly ever love me" vibes, no one ever will, because those vibes in themselves are unattractive, even if nothing else about you is.

If you could just believe in the possibility that something good *could* happen to you, then there's every reason to believe that it actually might. But so long as you keep acting the way you're acting, it isn't going to.

I'm not under-estimating how hard this would be; I'm not someone who thinks that someone with mental health issues can just "pull themselves together" - that's bullshit. But at the same time, however long and tough the process is, you have to make a start somewhere. And once you have, you may well find there's a positive feedback effect kicks in. Once you start acting like someone who might be desirable, people will start to treat you more like that; that will make you feel better; and that will make it easier to act the way you need to act.

So there's plenty of reasons for hope; but only if you're willing to start questioning your beliefs.

>>28114309
I also have bipolar type 1 and spent a month in a psych ward. Lost all friends, family thought I was irredeemably fucked in the head, had to repeat 18 months of uni after I decided I should probably go back a year or so later.

I lucked out and met up with a girl from a progressive family who encouraged me and gave me a stable environment to study while finishing my studies (I was 22/23 at this point). Was still living at home at this point.

Eventually I graduated, we married, now I'm stable and it's 15 years later. Life is good. I have a shitty relationship with my family and now I'm successful they like to pretend they didn't treat me like shit, but I won't forget. Whatever, fuck them.

Point is, stability is key to getting your shit on track. I was lucky, you might not be. You need to look for opportunities. Don't talk about your illness to others unless you have to. My work colleagues don't know because they don't need to, and stigma will be around forever even in progressive countries.

Sounds hard and it is but find someone you can share with. Get a small part time job if you don't have one. Try to do normie things. Don't get disheartened by set backs. We all have them and mental illness makes it harder to recover from them. But if you have support in place when bad shit happens then things will be easier.

I am partly to blame for this. A couple of years ago I had to work in the Netherlands and covid hit. Long story short she went through my Instagram and found the chats. Since then she never trusted me fully. But that was 2 and a half years ago.

I understood the mistake I made and since then I have always tried my best to make sure that she can't doubt me and that I am fully committed to her. Saying shit of the sorts that I have 10000 of whores and how I'm a piece of shit that I want to change the jealousy in her. She just kept confirming my points that jealousness is one of the most toxic emotions ever and everything I said went over her head.

I don't know what to do anymore, I really am trying my best but it's not working. It's really tiresome and it's really demotivating me (not only for the relationship but everything I do). So, got any advice Anons?

Like I said during my stay in the NL covid hit. I was working there, but lost the job due to obvious reasons. I was in a state of purgatory where I couldn't leave the country. During that time I started smoking a lot of weed just to make staying there more bearable. I started studying Psychology out of interest and started self analyzing myself because there wasn't anyone else. Slowly I started getting closed in my own head and I was feeling that I was really losing my sanity. Became a prisoner of my own head. Nothing out of the ordinary, everyone was more or less experiencing this. A month or two passed and I was slowly getting worse and worse.

Then in the span of a week I lost both of my grandparents. My only grandparents, unfortunately, I didn't manage to meet my other two in my conscious life. This completely destroyed me and my downward spiral truly began. I stared drinking heavy and smoking even heavier. That's when I started texting the other girl out desperation for attention and the thrill. I was a complete egoist and wasn't appreciating the woman that really mattered to me. Soon after this my mother got hospitalized due to the trauma of losing her parents and catching covid. This was basically the last straw for me and I completely went psycho, I was a different person, self loathing and overall just a degenerate.

With some connections I managed to catch a flight and return to my hometown so I can support my family. I started going to a psychologist and was desperately trying to save myself. Yet I was still a piece of shit and gf isn't stupid and felt that something wasn't alright. So she went through my Instagram and saw everything.

I know that this doesn't excuse me in any sort of way, but I really was losing my grip then.

Cooking is also a hobby for some and a life's work for others. Cook is both a job and a career as well as a passion for some. Maybe they're just bored. Maybe they love to cook. My old man will often cook an extra meal in the day or make snacks just to help fill the hours of his day, and he's a great cook so nobody ever complains.

You're absolutely right that the behavior they're showing is unhealthy but most people engage in some unhealthy behaviors. For most people its just smoking, overeating, undersleeping, too much stimulant, etc. etc. but there are some real crazies out there too. The stereotypes come from somewhere.

You might even consider eating some of the food, or inviting some friends over more often if they don't get a chance for much home cooking. They'll thank you for it.

If you're really dead set on changing people in your life to suit your needs you can consider having the conversation in a more cogent manner - finding a time when the defenses are down and going about it in such a way as to try to understand why they do what they do instead of berating them for it.

This sounds annoying OP, but I'd preface any reasonable answer with a question. Do you at all enjoy this dude's company when he's not on a bender about social justice?

If you do, then the secret to getting along with people of disparate ideologies and values has always been avoiding religion and politics as the topics of conversation. Everything is hyper-politicized now, but in the families and friendships where people are on opposite sides, this is usually the secret, as it always has been. Can't handle the conversations you have with that person on that subject? Avoid those subjects.

If you don't get anything out of the relationship though, I'd just stop going around him. You can't change people but you can change the people you're with.

This sort of thing bothers me a lot too but I've learned that trying to convince people of a point of view and actually change their minds is a much more nuanced thing than it initially appears and, a bit of a proverbial 'golden goose' moment, actually. It almost never happens - people who pretend to be convinced often just want the other person to shut up and go away. However, most people can recognize and respect the 'agree to disagree' line. If he can't manage that, and can't understand that lambasting you in conversation is making you uncomfortable after you've told him you don't appreciate it, then you're probably better off without him.

There is a variety of ways people experience what they call "anxiety," so it's hard to be specific without a fucking doctor's appointment or therapy. However, there are likely techniques to alleviate the physiological symptoms you experience. Some that help me are
>diaphragmatic breathing
>pelvic floor relaxing
>softening the gaze
>soft palette relaxing
>adjusting posture upright
These are techniques for a sympathetic nervous system response, aka "fight flight freeze." Maybe they'll work for you, maybe they won't, because
>There is a variety of ways people experience what they call "anxiety."
What you call anxiety could instead be mind racing, accelerated heartbeat, sweating, blood rushing to head, or something else entirely. Look up your symptoms, learn techniques, practice them a few days, then go out ands use them when you feel anxious.

Then, one of the best pieces of advice from the old PUAs is the three second rule. See a girl you like, count to three and go in. The longer you wait, the more you psyche yourself out, AND the less confident you seem to her. Plus, stalk around too long and you'll genuinely creep her out

here's what I've always done as Step 0:
1) be at a place I care about, i.e. college club (Habitat For Humanity, Chess Club, Film Club, etc)
2) Notice a girl I'm interested in
3) go up to her and introduce myself, ask if she minds if I sit next to her
4) over the course of days/weeks, get to know her and ask if she wants to meet up for coffee
5--> get to know her as a person and see if there's compatibility.

idk just don't get pushy? I'm a big fan of making my interactions clear, ask for permission to X, if she's cool for Y, is she interested in Z (given that it's not an internet-based thing)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28116922
Psychedelics are mostly safe. You should be in a safe environment with good music. A clean room.

You won't be hungry for like 12 hours and afterwards you are going to want something but something about acid makes meat seem repulsive so take this into account.

For most people tripping a few times is harmless but if your family has schizophrenics in it then it's best to avoid.

Bad trips can be really really abysmally bad and good trips can be stronger and feel better than heroin.

Having good music playing is the best thing you could have. Video games are also not a bad idea but avoid violence if possible. Go on a walk outside on the comedown when you feel really sober.

If everything works correctly the experience will be overwhelming and bewildering. Then on the come down you'll feel more sober than sober. Everything will feel like it makes more sense.

Psychedelics can change people's lives but it doesn't fix your life for you, just shows you stuff.

posts.sub: Family Assumptions
posts.com:
Is there an underlying assumption that everybody - no matter how capable - deserves a chance to get married and start a family? Most want to believe in some sort of meritocracy but will concede that some people just aren't fit for certain forms of success; being an astronaut takes hard work but also near-perfect genetics. Why then do we say everybody has the "right" to start a family?

I'm not some edgey teenage anti natalist - I do think family is generally a good thing. But I see so many incapable, negligent families and couples around me that I genuinely think some people are unaware of how unfit they are for such a life. So many of us have garbage interpersonal skills that only worsen once we enter a relationship. Money is also a huge factor. Our current economy has decimated household budgets and disrupted the division of labour and family roles. Families used to provide wealth and security but the former has drastically decreased despite the costs sky-rocketing in recent decades.

Bear in mind that family has historically been a necessity to survive. Modern life has mostly put an end to this though and most social theories argue that the only remaining legitimate needs for family is emotional + sexual regulation and teaching social skills to children.

Given this, what percentage of people do you think are truly fit to run a family and where is the cut-off? Just spit-ball some numbers. I'm not saying the state should regulate families - hell no. But rather I'm starting to see family less as a necessity and more of a luxury good that we would all benefit from, but only a few can attain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28117845
Cut back on stimulation any way that you can. >No music, no movies, no video games.
If you must put on something put on audiobooks, podcasts tend to also be saturated with high density sound to keep people's attention longer.
>meditate for 10 minutes/day more is better
>read (for fun) for 15 to 20 minutes
>cut back caffeine to half for a week then go down to a quarter of your regular intake

Then the usual stuff
>go to bed at roughly the same time every day
>wake up at exactly the same time everyday
>spend 30 minutes outside
>do light exercise (can often be a walk and combined with the above point)

Don't be afraid to take breaks either. work on your thesis for an hour take 20 minutes off and repeat. Schedule downtime in the evening to do things you enjoy. That helps with the feeling of always feeling like you should be working on stuff. I do this myself with my coursework. At 8pm, no matter what I stop for the day and give myself 3 hours before bed to clean up, mediate, read, etc..

Hope that helps.

I did flashcards every day for a year and know a ton of japanese now. Nowhere near fluent yet but I know enough to frequently notice translation errors in anime. Where the subtitles don't match the speech that is.

I started at 27 and lazy. I'm now 30 and n4-n3ish. You could do faster if you dedicate yourself.

Just remember that anything you don't know, learn it and you won't have to learn it again because you already know it.

The thing that actually got me started was realizing the dark souls pause menu has like 50 symbols in place of attributes. That's like 50 kanji I could memorize instead.

posts.com:
>>28112980
Not really, art will certainly be de-valued in the future, but judging by all the lawsuits over AI currently being worked on, it will likely be impossible to copyright or profit from AI art in the future, I.E if you were to make a comic made with AI images, it wouldn’t be likely that you could actually sell it legally as lawmakers are trying to make it so AI images cannot belong to you. The problem with AI (that is becoming more and more apparent every day) is that it’s not really “intelligence”, it’s an algorithm like any other, it is using pattern recognition that it has learned from millions of images created by real artists. When you create an AI image it’s essentially creating a Frankenstein monster of millions of copyrighted images, which results in a legal nightmare. There’s a phenomena with AI images where you often see the likenesses of real people in the images even when they’re not relevant to the prompt. Take pic related for example, it’s a still from an AI generated music video where the man is clearly William Shatner even though it’s not supposed to be. AI was pitched as being an intelligent mind creating art the same way a person does, only using other images as inspiration so it’s not copyright infringement, however it’s becoming more and more clear that it’s more simplistic than that and is essentially smashing many pre-existing images together and reproducing the results. It’s cool, but it’s going to be a nightmare in the future. They’ll probably make a legal version trained only on public domain images, but the output will not be nearly as impressive or varied.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28112980
The only thing this impacts is value, and people shouldn't be trying to turn hobbies into a job anyway. A job is a job because of transferable obligation - someone pays you to take care of a job that they're in turn being paid to do, which they then split up among employees in part or in whole. If people actually wanted to do the job, they would not be paying other people to pay other people to do the job. Simple as.

Alternatively you can bank on the idea that, rather than your job being something people don't want to do, it can be something other people don't know HOW to do, a skill like being an artist, but then you rely on the idea that the market for your skills will never be diluted by machine labor, immigrant labor, or just more humans being shit out on the planet. All told, not a steady basis for a job.

TL;DR Keep drawing if you like it, but don't expect it to pay your bills. Everyone needs a hobby.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28117931
You should be fine, OP. Its generally good to keep socializing - just find some people with a hobby that you click with, or maintain casual contact with the friends you have - but no, you don't have to engage in any of that if you don't want to, and you have the right to whatever boundaries or time constraints that you like. Just try to remember somewhere in the back of your mind that totally cutting yourself off from the world can distort your sense of reality - humans are social creatures, even the most devoted hermit needs to hear a human voice now and then.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

>>28112537
HPV is incurable, and can sometimes lead to cancer; if you get a strain which causes warts, the individual warts can be treated, but this is painful, and they will keep popping up for several years at least.

HIV is incurable; it is usually treatable, but the drugs are very expensive and can have nasty side effects; you need to take them for life. Occasionally the drugs stop working and people die.

Herpes is incurable, and infects you for life - outbreaks become less frequent with time, but they never stop; herpes simplex 2 is excruciatingly painful; there are drugs that will help treat an outbreak, but you can't take them constantly.

Chlamydia, syphilis and gonorrhoea are usually treatable with antibiotics, but antibiotic-resistant strains of gonorrhoea and syphilis are becoming steadily more common. Note that syphilis can cause insanity or death if it isn't treated, which happens more often than you'd think, because the initial symptoms disappear after a month or two, then it comes back with a vengeance years later, having quietly damaged your central nervous system in the mean time.

Hepatitis is untreatable - you will probably eventually recover from it after several years, but you'll be very sick indeed while you're waiting; it does sometimes kill.

There are other types of bacterial infection that you can pick up from sex; these are generally treatable with antibiotics.

>>28114526
It absolutely can make people appear less intelligent. Especially in academic settings. The horrible truth about ADHD is that no treatment can solve all the symptoms. You can get damn close if you work really hard, but the fact of the matter is your brain functions differently.
Here are some things to try(keep in mind every responds a little differently to treatment.)
- Adderall - this can make or break the affliction. For some, this can be a miracle drug that solves the majority of issues. Others find it overwhelming and exasperating of the issues. Typically the former is more likely to be true.
- caffeine - literally the same as before but to a lesser degree and helps with some things Adderall doesn't cover.
- meditation (God help you) - this can help in strengthening your frontal lobe and keeping chemicals in proper balance in your brain.
You can do this anon. Get doctor's note and anything you can. You can do whatever neurotypicals can do, you just need a little extra time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28107601
I went to college right out of high school and that's what happened to me. I dropped out and went to work.

I'm now back in college now 13 years later and I'm getting basically straight A's. What changed is I now know what it is I want to be doing with some certainty, rather than doing it because I feel like I have to or that I'm expected to. I have a degree and a job in mind and I actively want those things. Having that end goal in mind radically changed college from a slog I had to do into something now that I (mostly) enjoy, although that doesn't mean it's not stressful.

If you struggle with procrastination and distraction. Set up a specific schedule. There are lots of excel schedule templates and allocate your time specifically, what days at what times and for how long you are going to work on coursework. Also be sure to get out of the house and take breaks. Light exercise can also help calm the mind, short meditations can also be good. Also having a designated space is helpful, but if you're like me and don't have a big enough apartment to do that, going to the college or just even a nearby library can help.

Also a big part of my success was cutting back from a 'full time' course load to 2 classes a term, it's massively helpful in both stress and workload. I go slower and (arguably) spend more money, but I've passed nearly every class with an A, so I see it as being a worthwhile tradeoff.

Try some of that stuff, but also make sure you can answer the 'why' question. If you can't than maybe it's time to figure that out. Spend 20 minutes a day googling stuff. If you're interested in Computer Science. Investigate specialized fields of CS and figure out niches that sound interesting and then go look to see if/what jobs of that kind are available in your area to see if it's actually a job that exists in meaningful quantities in the area you live or an area you are willing/want to move to, and do this for one aspect of CS every day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28107936
*every day until you have a list of 3 or 4 specific jobs that sound interesting to you.

That way if you get further along in the process and it stops being appealing for whatever reason you still have a good handful you can peruse with the degree you're working on. If you can't find at least 3, investigate other degrees and if you still can't find 3, maybe it's time to reconsider being in college, maybe working full time just makes more sense right now, like I had to do.

>>28108136
Modafinil and Piracetam or Aniracetam will all help with focus. You need to force yourself to work- "Wear the hat" so to speak. I'd also look into Delta THC Gummies- I had great luck with HHC for helping me feel good throughout the day and being more productive. Make little goals and stick with them.
Exercise helps, more than you think. You only need 20-30 mins of cardio, important thing is getting the heart rate up to 170-180 BPM.
Vitamins are great too. I prefer the mens sport vitamins from GNC, but you do you.
Whatever you do, make sure to not let yourself get behind, if possible- stressing yourself out will mean you work slower.
If nothing else, wear the hat- Just pretend you're some giga chad programmer who's done this for years and fake it till you make it. Put in the hours of work and Get it done. You got this anon, just gotta believe in yourself and put in the work.

Also, I recommend adding NAC to any of the stimulants mentioned above, it has some neuroprotective effects. Only need 600mg a day or so.

If you're asking what is the best way to find a good partner, then that depends. You should already have an idea of things you expect, and things you won't tolerate in a partner before dating anyone, so if a guy you date shows a dealbreaking trait right away, you already have the information you need to stop and move on. It gets more muddy if you are just getting to know a guy, and even though he shows some concerning traits/red flags, you haven't identified any dealbreakers firsthand. This is mostly up to your intuition and risk tolerance: how many warning signs that you're not a good match are you willing to deal with before the risk is no longer worth the potential of getting a positive surprise?
At the end of the day, it's still entirely your right and *obligation* to not date a guy you don't want to.

>>28118205
>The thing is he’s the only guy who has wanted to marry me
I can only think of two meanings for this after your question in the OP, and neither is good.
Either you've only dated for a little bit (a couple months or less), and this sperg has already asked to marry you--which, even if it's a wholesome thought with no weird intent, is premature and a sign for concern--or you've been dating for a long time despite you not having ever been attracted to him. While some of the people on here will seethe at women for "leading men on", wasting potentially years of someone's youth on a relationship you were never invested in is obviously wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28114592
>Are there any noticeable signs of depression so that I can know if he is faking it or not?
Absolutely none, no.

It is characteristic of mental illnesses that they take the form of a cluster of symptoms that tend to occur together; but no one depressed person will have all of the possible symptoms, and there is no one symptom that all depressed people have. The illness manifests itself in many different ways. And most of the possible symptoms are not visible to the outside observer.

Depression can also come and go, so he may well be okay on some days but bad on others.

posts.com: How do I become a capable person?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Trial and error. Keep going even after you fail. Believe in yourself even when those around you don't. Pick worthy, practical goals when it comes to self-improvement and your future prospects, then keeping aiming for them even when there are setbacks. Utilize resources and courses online like self-help books etc. Try to meet and be friends with more people that are smarter, are more successful, or even just have a positive/interesting mentality that you can learn from. Find streamers/content creators/bloggers that have their shit together in the real world that you can learn from.

My friend and I were both fuck-ups that could hardy keep minimum wage jobs. But after about a decade of the above and some post-secondary, we're both in good-paying white collar professions. I'm about to buy my first property and start out-doing a lot of the same family members that instilled doubt in me years ago.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cognitive reframing will help
I was so far gone that socialising was causing me to "relive" negative life experiences and full blown panic
It's really a matter of convincing yourself not to be afraid of shit. Embracing situations as challenges and trying to do well at the challenges.
The beauty of this is that you don't have to overdo anything, just make small efforts to make small steps in doing things that make you terrible uncomfortable and/or afraid/have flashbacks. When you successfully achieve small victories, celebrate mentally and reward yourself with something.
I honestly can't say without really knowing what you go through but you shouldn't kys and it can get better.
I was completely brainfucked and drugfucked and socially paralysed for around 8 years and am making progress after 2 years of the aforementioned.
Sorry if it isn't what you wanted to hear but yeah, try to invite love for everything into yourself. It won't "cure" anything but it'll help

posts.com:
Something to keep in mind is that therapy mostly exist for people to understand or find out what's their real problem. You still have to do the heavy work to fix those things. People think that a therapist will tell them something that will "fix" their brains, but that's not the case.
They can guide you, they can help you find ways to deal with your problems, but they can't really fix them for you.

Some time ago I was scared to look for a job, I didn't feel prepared enough to get one. I felt like I was going to ruin any chance to get a decent job. I went to therapy and realized my problem was my self-esteem and anxiety. The therapist didn't tell me "ok you'll do this to get a job" but she guided me to deal with my anxiety and improve my self-esteem, which later lead to me finding a job.

That said, there are way too many bad therapists.
